intro: Galium tunetanum var. hirtum, commonly known as the hairy bedstraw, is a flowering plant belonging to the Rubiaceae family. It is characterized by its prostrate or ascending growth habit, with slender, hairy stems that often root at the nodes. The plant produces small, white to pinkish flowers arranged in clusters, typically blooming in early summer. Its leaves are opposite, ovate to elliptic in shape, and covered with fine hairs, giving it a distinctive textured appearance. Native to regions of North Africa and the Mediterranean, it thrives in dry, rocky or sandy soils.
